dt: {bc}a short prayer comprising an invocation, petition, and conclusion
{bc}one preceding the eucharistic Epistle and varying with the day

et: Middle English {it}collecte, collet,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}collecte,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}collēcta,{/it} perhaps going back to Late Latin, in sense "gathering place, assembly" (assuming the original reference was to {it}ōrātiō ad collēctam,{/it} a prayer recited at the congregation's gathering place), going back to Latin, feminine of {it}collēctus,{/it} past participle of {it}colligere{/it} "to gather together, assemble, accumulate" {ma}{mat|collect:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: a short prayer comprising an invocation, petition, and conclusion; specifically, often capitalized : one preceding the eucharistic Epistle and varying with the day

dt: {bc}to bring together into one body or place
{bc}to gather or exact from a number of persons or sources
{bc}to gather an accumulation of (objects) especially as a hobby
{bc}to claim as due and receive payment for

dt.t: went to {wi}collect{/wi} her at the train station

dt: {bc}to come together in a band, group, or mass {bc}{sx|gather||}

pt: {sc}gather{/sc} {sc}collect{/sc} {sc}assemble{/sc} {sc}congregate{/sc} mean to come or bring together into a group, mass, or unit. {sc}gather{/sc} is the most general term for bringing or coming together from a spread-out or scattered state.
{sc}collect{/sc} often implies careful selection or orderly arrangement.
{sc}assemble{/sc} implies an ordered union or organization of persons or things often for a definite purpose.
{sc}congregate{/sc} implies a spontaneous flocking together into a crowd or huddle.

et: Middle English {it}collecten{/it} "to accumulate, infer, calculate," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}collecter,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}collēctus,{/it} past participle of {it}colligere{/it} "to gather together, assemble, accumulate, pull (oneself) together," from {it}col-,{/it} assimilated variant of {it}com-{/it} {et_link|com-|com-} + {it}legere{/it} "to gather by picking or plucking, select, choose" {ma}{mat|legend|}{/ma}
shortdef: to bring together into one body or place
to gather or exact from a number of persons or sources
to gather an accumulation of (objects) especially as a hobby

dt: {bc}to be paid for by the receiver

shortdef: to be paid for by the receiver

dt.t: I {it}collected up{/it} the dishes and brought them to the kitchen.
The children {it}collected{/it} their toys {it}up{/it} and put them away.

et: partly from Latin {it}recollectus{/it}, past participle of {it}recolligere{/it}, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}colligere{/it} to collect; partly from {it}re-{/it} + {it}collect{/it}
shortdef: to collect again; especially : rally, recover
